Unhappy Stranger!  for no sculptur'd shone</br>Protects thy relics from the rustic spade;</br>No brier-bound hillock, by its form, has shewn</br>The little spot of earth where thou wert laid.
Yet shall the Muse bestrew with flow'rs thy grave,</br>And mark the vanity of human pride,</br>Mark how alike, the wise, the fair, the brave,</br>May undistinguish'd in the Tomb abide.
Erewhile, perhaps, his breast with ardor glow'd,</br>By courage high, and native freedom fir'd,</br>Before the Saxon, his heart's blood out-flow'd,</br>And, full of wounds and glory, he expir'd.
Perhaps, a Martyr to his Country's cause,</br>Against Rebellion his keen blade he tried,</br>Fought to restore her violated laws,</br>And in the glorious conflict — smil'd, and died.
When Winter wild the plain in snow array'd,</br>To the next Mart he pick'd his dang'rous way,</br>The gaping Pit his wand'ring steps betray'd,</br>And treacherous hid him from returning Day.
The faithful Partner of his humble lot,</br>Impatient, oft look'd out with tearful eye,</br>Gaz'd on the latchet of the straw-thatch'd cot,</br>And saw it still unlifted with a sigh.
Perhaps, impell'd by Ruin and Despair,</br>'Gainst his own life he rais'd an impious hand,</br>The eye of Justice frown'd, tho' through a tear,</br>And gave him burial in the public strand.
Rather, perhaps, remote from native home,</br>Far, far remote from every hand to save,</br>The grim Assassin pierc'd him thro' the gloom,</br>And hid him, reeking, in unhallow'd grave.
Or, by pale Want, unknown, unfed, he fell,</br>No friendly hand to close his hollow eyes,</br>No Village Clerk toll'd out his passing knell,</br>No Priest perform'd his funeral obsequies.
Beneath the shelter of that aged Yew,</br>Commit his relics to their clay-cold bed,</br>On his poor Bones the closing Earth bestrew,</br>And venerate the Manes of the Dead.</br>
